conclusion: The problem involves two cars A and B traveling on a straight road with their velocity-time graphs provided, and the task is to find the maximum distance between them between two instances when they are side by side.
The velocity-time graph shows Car A starting at v = 0, accelerating until t = 10s, then maintaining a constant velocity of 40 m/s, while Car B starts at v = 0 and accelerates linearly with time.
Car A's velocity function is v_A(t) = 4t m/s for 0 ≤ t ≤ 10 and v_A(t) = 40 m/s for t > 10.
Car B's velocity function is v_B(t) = 2t m/s for t ≥ 0.
The position of Car A is x_A(t) = 2t² for 0 ≤ t ≤ 10 and x_A(t) = 40t - 200 for t > 10.
The position of Car B is x_B(t) = t² for t ≥ 0.
The cars are side by side when x_A(t) = x_B(t).
For 0 ≤ t ≤ 10, solving 2t² = t² gives t = 0, meaning the cars are side by side at t = 0.
For t > 10, solving 40t - 200 = t² gives t ≈ 34.14 or t ≈ 5.86, but only t ≈ 34.14 is valid since t > 10.
The cars are side by side at t = 0 and t ≈ 34.14s, but this conflicts with the given information that they are side by side at t = 30s.
The graph shows Car A and Car B intersecting at t = 20s, v = 40 m/s, indicating they have the same velocity at this point.
Having the same velocity at t = 20s does not mean the cars are at the same position.
At t = 30s, the cars are side by side, so x_A(30) = x_B(30).
Using x_A(30) = x_B(30), solving 40·30 - 200 + C = 30² gives C = -100.
The updated position functions are x_A(t) = 40t - 300 for t > 10 and x_B(t) = t².
For t > 10, solving 40t - 300 = t² gives t = 30 or t = 10, meaning the cars are side by side at t = 10s and t = 30s.
